I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  To integrate its Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS)1 into 
the provincial socioeconomic development plans (SEDPs) and to implement its own SEDP,2  
2006–2010, the Government of Viet Nam requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for 
technical assistance (TA) to help Thua Thien Hué and Quang Tri provinces strengthen their 
capacity to strategize their poverty reduction and growth programs for faster and sustainable 
socioeconomic development. The request was pursued by the leaders of the two provinces 
during the seminar on sustainable regional development strategy conducted jointly by ADB and 
the Development Strategy Institute of the Ministry of Planning and Investment (MPI) in Hué on 
18 February 2005,3 and echoed during ADB’s Mekong management team retreat on the new 
country strategy and program (CSP) for Viet Nam in Hué in late February 2005. A TA fact-
finding mission (FFM) was fielded from 8–10 April 2005 to discuss the TA design with the 
Government  counterparts  and  finalize  the  TA.  The  FFM  discussed  and  reached  an 
understanding with the Government on the goal, purpose and outputs, methodology and key 
activities, cost and financing, implementation arrangements, and outline terms of reference for 
the TA. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Viet Nam’s impressive record of reducing poverty in recent years, particularly halving 
poverty within a decade, is largely attributed to its strong economic growth performance. The 
SEDP commits the Government to maintaining the momentum of growth and further reducing 
poverty by 15–18% by 2010. Meeting the needs of the poor below the national poverty line, 
however, is perceived as difficult because they live in remote highlands and mountains or in 
pockets of inner coastal areas. Similarly, the impressive gains in poverty reduction are still 
fragile and many people, who are just above the poverty line, remain vulnerable to shocks, 
which could push them back below the poverty line.5 
 
3.  A recent joint report6 on the experiences and lessons from Central Highland region notes 
that, to sustain the current growth and poverty reduction rate, the integration of CPRGS into the 
SEDP is critical for the central and local governments. The report calls for a sharper focus on 
the provinces to adequately address (i) entrenched poverty; and (ii) local level governance 
issues (including institutional capability for planning, monitoring and service delivery, grassroots 
democracy, and social exclusion), gender mainstreaming, and targeted programs for ethnic 
minorities. These issues were similarly echoed in the review reports of ADB TA 4163-VIE and

4.  The Government recognizes that, to sustain the high growth and poverty reduction rates, 
it needs to intensify decentralization and devolve more responsibilities to the provinces. The 
SEDP will incorporate elements of the CPRGS and Viet Nam Development Goals (VDGs) to 
strengthen the quality of socioeconomic plans at all levels through planning reforms. The new 
SEDPs  promote  (i)  “bottom-up”  instead  of  the  traditional  “top-down”  approaches;  (ii) 
participatory approaches, involving representatives from the poor, women, and ethnic minorities; 
(iii) addressing non-income poverty to achieve the VDGs; and (iv) results-based local planning 
and monitoring. Provincial leaders and government officials have voiced that these tasks are 
difficult due to capacity constraints. 
 
5.  ADB’s CSP, which is being aligned to the SEDP, envisages helping the Government 
devolve  more  responsibilities  to  the  provinces.  The  CSP  will  focus  sharply  on  provincial 
development  strategy,  policies,  and  programs;  institutional  capabilities;  and  investment 
requirements, especially along the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) economic corridors such 
as the East–West Economic Corridor (EWEC), which passes through Thua Thien Hué and 
Quang Tri provinces.  
 
6.  The provinces have identified the following as key development issues: (i) strategic 
planning capacity for fast and sustainable socioeconomic development is limited, and results-
based management is a completely new territory; (ii) understanding and incorporation of the 
CPRGS and VDGs in local socioeconomic planning is limited; (iii) poverty reduction programs 
need to focus on sandy coastal and remote mountain areas; (iv) physical planning is required to 
locate  households  and  small  enterprises  in  an  industrial  zone  so  that  new  and  up-scaled 
enterprises will not only create jobs for the poor but also protect the physical environment; (v) 
poverty is related to environmental degradation (e.g., the lagoon in Quang Dien district of Thua 
Thien Hué; (vi) poverty reduction and growth are regional issues that call for a comprehensive 
approach to promoting synergy among development initiatives in adjoining provinces and along 
the EWEC; (vii) ethnic minorities must change their behavior to improve their livelihoods; (viii) 
proactive  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs)  must  be  promoted  to  respond  to 
opportunities  created  by  infrastructure  development;  and  (ix)  effective  local  resource 
mobilization is needed. The SEDP8 will target poverty reduction more intensely than previous 
plans to reach the poor in remote or bypassed locations. The provinces must have the capacity 
to support these initiatives. 
 
7.  Since Viet Nam is among the four countries where ADB is piloting its results-based 
CSPs, and since the SEDP is results-oriented, the proposed TA will be an excellent opportunity 
to introduce the concept and tools of results-based management to the provinces. The lessons 
learned or results gained from this TA will directly feed into the annual CSP update for Viet Nam 
and preparation of annual provincial plans, as well as assist in the design of interventions in the 
Central Highlands, EWEC, and southern and northern economic corridors under ADB’s regional 
cooperation strategy and program for the GMS. The outcomes will help form the basis for

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The  goal  of  the  project  is  to  help  Thua  Thien  Hué  and  Quang  Tri  formulate  and 
implement strategy and programs for faster but sustainable poverty reduction and economic 
growth within the SEDP framework. Its purpose is to help the provincial people’s committees 
(PPCs) and the provincial departments of planning and investment (DPIs) (i) conduct a policy 
and institutional analysis of Thua Thien Hué and Quang Tri to identify and address bottlenecks 
in resource flows and service delivery; (ii) implement the SEDP, particularly in preparing annual 
socioeconomic development plans, taking into account gender and ethnic dimensions, and 
formulating targeted programs for the poor and vulnerable; (iii) conduct sector studies to identify 
investible projects, considering opportunities offered by the EWEC  and Lao-Bao economic 
zone, Hué economic zone (under construction), and the deep-water port; (iv) identify project and 
program financing alternatives (including from the state, private, and foreign resources); and (v) 
train government officials in strategic planning and results-based management.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The TA will be designed and implemented in close consultation with provincial leaders 
and government officials. This process approach will allow provincial leaders and government 
officials to learn by doing. The major activities and outputs of the TA will be (i) a detailed 
analysis  of  strengths,  weaknesses,  opportunities,  and  threats  in  the  context  of  fast  but 
sustainable socioeconomic development; (ii) quantitative poverty analysis to identify trends and 
characteristics; (iii) introduction of a participatory poverty and governance assessment, based 
on  interviews  and  discussions  (report  card)  with  local  people  and  officials  at  selected 
communes; (iv) institutional analysis and a study report on selected sectors (e.g., agriculture 
crop diversification, SMEs); (v) a results-oriented poverty reduction program for Quang Dien 
district in Thua Thien Hué, with focus on lagoon environment protection and poverty reduction, 
and for selected communes in mountain districts of Quang Tri, with focus on ethnic minorities; 
(vi) on-the-job training of provincial leaders and government officials and academic institutions 
in concepts and methods in the above analytical studies; and (vii) training modules and seminar 
proceedings on strategic planning and results-based socioeconomic development management. 
These  activities  and  related  outputs  will  lead  to  high-quality  socioeconomic  development 
planning and implementation, which will speed up poverty reduction and economic growth in the 
provinces. 
 
10.  Expected  Development  Results  and  Outcomes.  The  main  expected  results  and 
deliverables of the TA for Thua Thien Hué and Quang Tri in the short term will include (i) 
adoption of results-oriented and strategic socioeconomic development planning; (ii) adoption of 
a participatory process in planning and monitoring of poverty reduction programs; (iii) improved 
revenue  generation;  (iv)  increase  in  the  number  of  SMEs  and  exports;  and  (iv)  improved 
institutional  capabilities  to  undertake  policy  analysis,  sector  studies,  and  results-based 
socioeconomic  development  management.  In  the  long  term,  the  provinces  will  achieve  (i) 
significant  improvement  in  socioeconomic  development  indicators  (income  and  non-income 
poverty, and VDGs in the provinces); and (ii) stronger synergy between provincial and national 
socioeconomic  development  programs  and  subregional  economic  cooperation  initiatives  to 
increase economic linkages and to reduce poverty.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,125,000 equivalent, comprising a foreign 
exchange cost of $270,000 and a local currency cost of $855,000 equivalent. The Government 
has requested ADB to finance $900,000 equivalent, including $270,000 in foreign exchange and 
$630,000 equivalent in local currency. The TA will be financed by ADB on a grant basis, from 
the Cooperation Fund in Support of the Formulation and Implementation of National Poverty 
Reduction Strategies (NPRS). The Government will finance the balance of the local currency 
costs, amounting to $225,000 equivalent in-kind to cover office accommodation, counterpart 
staff, administrative and logistic support, and other required services. Details of the TA cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  TA implementation will require (i) 20 person-months of international consultants on an 
intermittent basis, for strategic development planning and results-based management, lagoon 
environmental  protection,  poverty  reduction,  crop  diversification,  SME  development,  and 
training;  and  (ii)  about  72  person-months  of  domestic  consultants  for  project  coordination, 
strategic  development  planning  and  results-based  management,  lagoon  environmental 
protection and poverty reduction, crop diversification, SME development, and training. National 
and  provincial  universities,  research  institutes,  and  nongovernment  organizations  will  be 
considered  for  knowledge  partnerships  in  undertaking  some  of  the  envisaged  activities. 
Consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants, 
and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic  consultants. 
Consultants  will  be  recruited  as  individuals,  starting  tentatively  from  November  2005  to 
November 2007. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. The ADB Viet 
Nam Resident Mission will administer the TA in close consultation with MPI and with the PPCs 
and DPIs of Thua Thien Hué and Quang Tri. Equipment will be procured in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement.  
 
13.  The PPCs will be the TA executive agencies, responsible for the overall coordination 
and management of the project, including (i) coordinating with ADB and Government agencies, 
and (ii) ensuring that national approvals are obtained on time. The DPIs will be responsible for 
overall  project  implementation.  The  project  will  be  managed  through  the  provincial  project 
management units (PMUs) to be established within the DPI offices. The team will include 
consultants and DPI staff members. As the TA covers two provinces, the project steering 
committee will provide central coordination. It will be chaired by a director-level official of the 
Foreign Economic Relations Department of MPI, and members will include the vice chairs of 
Thua  Thien  Hué  and  Quang  Tri,  a  deputy  director  of  the  Regional  and  Local  Planning 
Department of MPI, selected sectoral provincial departments, the chair of Quang Dien district, 
representatives of research institutes and universities, and ADB. The steering committee will 
meet semiannually to review implementation progress and guide project activities.   
 
14.  Evaluation of the direct and indirect benefits on poverty reduction and/or the poor will be 
done through the periodic reviews of the public investment plans and provincial budgets to 
ensure that adequate percentage of investments are targeted at the poor or related activities. 
Likewise, the provincial PMUs will ensure that resource allocation is prioritized and directed at 
financing  the  planned  targeted  interventions.  Implementation  progress,  including  impact  on 
poverty or on the lives of the poor, will be circulated to all stakeholders through annual reports. 
ADB and the Government will carry out a joint annual review. The consultants will produce (i) an 
inception report, within 2 weeks after the TA starts; (ii) a midterm report, within 12 months; and

5
(iii) a final report at project or assignment completion. The TA is tentatively scheduled to 
commence in November 2005 and end in November 2007. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 to the Government 
of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Cooperation Fund in Support of the 
Formulation and Implementation of National Poverty Reduction Strategies for Support to Thua 
Thien Hué and Quang Tri Provinces for Sustainable Poverty Reduction and Growth Programs, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS1 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require 20 person-months of international and 72 
person-months  of  domestic  consultants,  divided  between  Thua  Thien  Hué  and  Quang  Tri 
provinces.  
 
A.  International Consultants (20 person-months) 
 
2.   The  strategic  planning  and  results-based  management  specialist  (6  person-months, 
team leader), to be based in Thua Thien Hué, will supervise all activities for Hué and coordinate 
with his or her counterpart in Quang Tri to ensure that all the TA’s work follows the plans and 
timeline. The specialist (6 person-months) to be based in Quang Tri will perform similar roles.  
 
3.   The  consultant  will  help  provincial  people’s  committees  (PPCs)  and  the  provincial 
departments of planning and investment (DPIs) formulate and implement the Socioeconomic 
Development Plan (SEDP), 2006–2010, particularly through annual plan preparation, taking into 
account  sector  and  thematic  priorities  and  potential  economic  opportunities  offered  by 
provincial, national, and subregional infrastructure development, and provide training in strategic 
planning and results-based management to counterpart government officials. The specialist will 
also identify and develop relevant provincial socioeconomic and sector indicators that can be 
used to monitor and evaluate the SEDP’s progress. The international consultant should have a 
university degree, relevant skills, and comprehensive experience in the issues to be addressed, 
and relevant work experience in developing and transition economies. Work experience in Viet 
Nam would be an advantage. The assignment will be for 6 person-months, intermittently. The 
consultant will also guide the project team through electronic media. 
 
4.  In particular, the consultant will (i) take stock of and analyze the perceived needs from 
the various government levels (central, province, district, commune) and planning processes, 
government initiatives, and economic opportunities offered by infrastructure development and 
cross-border  trade  facilitation  in  the  region;  (ii)  undertake  a  strengths,  weaknesses, 
opportunities, threats (SWOT) analysis of the province and recommend ways to formulate 
strategy  for  fast  but  sustainable  socioeconomic  development;  (iii)  review  the  current 
development  planning  process,  budgeting  process,  financing  alternatives,  expenditure 
management, and result indicators; (iv) identify gaps in planning, budgeting, financing, social 
inclusion,  and  measurable  result  indicators,  and  develop  proposals  to  improve  strategic 
planning and results monitoring; (v) help prepare results-oriented annual socioeconomic plan 
incorporating provincial socioeconomic development priorities and sector development needs in 
a provincial as well as regional context within the SEDP framework; (vi) help design targeted

5.  The environment protection (lagoon) and poverty reduction specialist (2 person-months) 
will be based in Thua Thien Hué. The PPC has identified degradation of the lagoon environment 
in Quang Dien district as a serious threat to the local physical as well as socioeconomic 
environment. One third of Quang Dien’s population is dependent on the lagoon, which covers 
4,500 hectares (21% of the total district area). Fishery and fishing activities, including shrimp 
farming, are threatened by the outbreak of waterborne diseases. While the larger part of the 
lagoon is under the two communes in the district, the rest belongs to other districts in Thua 
Thien Hué and neighboring Da Nang. Working closely with the project team, DPI and relevant 
provincial departments, local communes, and local people, the specialist will undertake an 
environmental assessment and poverty analysis and formulate an action program to protect the 
environment and ensure the livelihood of the local inhabitants, fisherfolk, and farmers, including 
cost estimates and timelines. The specialist should have at least a university degree, relevant 
skills and comprehensive experience in lagoon environmental and poverty-related issues, and 
relevant international work experience. Work experience in Viet Nam would be an advantage.
